gov.usgs.anss.PGM

Class PGM

  • java.lang.Object
    • gov.usgs.anss.PGM.PGM

  • public class PGM
extends java.lang.Object
    This class was largely adapted from C code from other PGM calculations.

      • peak_ground

        public static SM_INFO peak_ground(java.lang.String seed,
                                  java.lang.String QUID,
                                  java.lang.String auth,
                                  java.util.GregorianCalendar trig,
                                  java.util.GregorianCalendar start,
                                  double[] Data,
                                  int npts,
                                  int itype,
                                  double dt,
                                  java.io.PrintStream out)
        **************************************************************************** subroutine for estimation of ground motion * * input: * Data - data array * npts - number of points in timeseries * itype - units for timeseries. 1=disp 2=vel 3=acc * dt - sample spacing in sec * return: * SM_INFO object * null - if an * * **************************************************************************** @param seed The 12
        Parameters:
        seed - 12 character SEED name
        QUID - the Quake ID as a string
        auth - The quake author as a string
        trig - The trigger time, first motion time
        start - the start time of the time series
        Data - The data array in
        npts - The number of points in data array
        itype - 1=disp, 2=velocity, 3=acc
        dt - Sample spacing in seconds
        out - logging printstream
        Returns:
        AN SM_INFO object containing the computed parameters

      • locut

        public static void locut(double[] s,
                         int nd,
                         double fcut,
                         double delt,
                         int nroll,
                         int icaus)
        **************************************************************************** Butterworth locut filter order 2*nroll (nroll<=8) * (see Kanasewich, Time Sequence Analysis in Geophysics, * Third Edition, University of Alberta Press, 1981) * written by W. B. Joyner 01/07/97 * * s[j] input = the time series to be filtered * output = the filtered series * dimension of s[j] must be at least as large as * nd+3.0*float(nroll)/(fcut*delt) * nd = the number of points in the time series * fcut = the cutoff frequency * delt = the timestep * nroll = filter order * causal if icaus.eq.1 - zero phase shift otherwise * * The response is given by eq. 15.8-6 in Kanasewich: * Y = sqrt((f/fcut)**(2*n)/(1+(f/fcut)**(2*n))), * where n = 2*nroll * * Dates: 01/07/97 - Written by Bill Joyner * 12/17/99 - D. Boore added check for fcut = 0.0, in which case * no filter is applied. He also cleaned up the * appearance of the code (indented statements in * loops, etc.) * 02/04/00 - Changed "n" to "nroll" to eliminate confusion with * Kanesewich, who uses "n" as the order (=2*nroll) * 03/01/00 - Ported to C by Jim Luetgert * * **************************************************************************** @param s The input time series
        Parameters:
        nd - Number of data points in series
        fcut - The cutoff frequence (HZ?)
        delt - The digitizing period in seconds
        nroll - The filter order
        icaus - if 1 zero phase sift, otherwise response is given above

      • rdrvaa

        public static void rdrvaa(double[] acc,
                          int na,
                          double omega,
                          double damp,
                          double dt,
                          RD rd)
        **************************************************************************** rdrvaa * * This is a modified version of "Quake.For", originally * written by J.M. Roesset in 1971 and modified by * Stavros A. Anagnostopoulos, Oct. 1986. The formulation is * that of Nigam and Jennings (BSSA, v. 59, 909-922, 1969). * Dates: 02/11/00 - Modified by David M. Boore, based on RD_CALC * 03/01/00 - Ported to C by Jim Luetgert * * acc = acceleration time series * na = length of time series * omega = 2*pi/per * damp = fractional damping (e.g., 0.05) * dt = time spacing of input * rd = relative displacement of oscillator * rv = relative velocity of oscillator * aa = absolute acceleration of oscillator * **************************************************************************** @param acc The accelleration time series
        Parameters:
        na - The length of the time series
        omega - 2*PI/PER
        damp - Damping fraction (e.g.,0.05)
        dt - Time spacing of samples in seconds
        rd - This is a convenience obje to contain the rd, rv, and aa values
